Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed noun phrase with possessive construct
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A term of endearment meaning 'my sun and stars', expressing deep affection or love.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: My beloved / the one I love deeply
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from Dothraki courtship traditions under the Khals’ moons; symbolizes constancy and warmth.
First Example Sentence: Anha ray shekh ma shieraki anni ajjin ma ray.
Second Example Sentence: Yer vos dothrak mae shekh ma shieraki anni ven mae.
Third Example Sentence: Mae ven mae vos hash mae shekh ma shieraki anni.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Used to honor someone as noble or powerful; ‘as radiant as a queen’.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: A person of high grace or authority
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Originates from early Dothraki reverence for female leaders; now used figuratively in speeches.
First Example Sentence: Mae ray vezhof ma khaleesi ven okren.
Second Example Sentence: Yer hash mae ven mae vezhof ma khaleesi ma vos mae.
Third Example Sentence: Anha ray mae vezhof ma khaleesi ven mae anhaan.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: ‘The world does not move for him’; used to mean someone unimportant or powerless.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Used among Dothraki warriors to mock boastful riders who have lost prestige.
First Example Sentence: Anha vos ray mae ven rhaeshisar vosechi mae.
Second Example Sentence: Mae hash mae ven rhaeshisar vosechi mae ven vezhvenari.
Third Example Sentence: Yer ray mae ven mae vos rhaeshisar vosechi mae.

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common among nomads when efforts yield no gain, linked to failed hunts.
First Example Sentence: Anha dothrak mae ven mae vorsa ma ray.
Second Example Sentence: Mae hash mae ven mae vorsa ma ray ajjin.
Third Example Sentence: Yer ray mae ven mae vorsa ma ray ma vos mae.

Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: He is lucky / fortune favors him
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Draws on Dothraki belief that the world (rhaesh) has moods favoring warriors.
First Example Sentence: Mae ray mae ven rhaesh ajjin mae ven vezhof.
Second Example Sentence: Anha hash mae ven mae rhaesh ajjin mae ven vezhof.
Third Example Sentence: Yer ray mae ven mae vos rhaesh ajjin mae ven vezhof.

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to warriors concealing emotion before a raid; now used metaphorically for deception.
First Example Sentence: Mae hash mae ven athdrivar mae ven shekh.
Second Example Sentence: Yer vos ray mae ven mae athdrivar mae ven shekh ajjin.
Third Example Sentence: Anha ray mae ven mae athdrivar mae ven shekh ma ray.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Means ‘he is in trouble’ or ‘in deep danger’.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Linked to a rider falling from his horse (qora) — a symbol of peril.
First Example Sentence: Mae hash mae ven qora mae vekha ajjin.
Second Example Sentence: Yer ray mae ven mae qora mae vekha ma vos mae.
Third Example Sentence: Anha ray mae ven mae qora mae vekha ven mae.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Means ‘he boasts too much’ or ‘is full of himself’.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Based on imagery of a stallion’s swollen chest, associated with pride.
First Example Sentence: Mae hash mae ven vezh ofrak mae ma vos mae.
Second Example Sentence: Yer ray mae ven mae vezh ofrak mae ajjin.
Third Example Sentence: Anha vos ray mae ven mae vezh ofrak mae ven mae.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Means ‘he meets his fate’ or ‘receives justice’.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: He faces consequences / justice is done
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Used in Dothraki epics describing warriors punished by destiny.
First Example Sentence: Mae hash mae ven okren mae ven mae ajjin.
Second Example Sentence: Yer ray mae ven mae okren mae ven mae ma ray.
Third Example Sentence: Anha ray mae ven mae okren mae ven mae ven shekh.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Means ‘the leader is nothing’; used when mocking fallen authority.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: He has lost power / no longer important
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Emerges from Dothraki war camps after failed raids; mocks dethroned khals.
First Example Sentence: Mae hash mae ven vezhvenari ray mae vosi ajjin.
Second Example Sentence: Yer ray mae ven mae vezhvenari ray mae vosi ma vos mae.
Third Example Sentence: Anha vos ray mae ven mae vezhvenari ray mae vosi ven mae.
